sen.j: 狩野 養信（かのう おさのぶ、寛政8年7月26日 (旧暦)（1796年8月18日） - 弘化3年5月19日 (旧暦)（1846年6月12日））は江戸時代の木挽町家狩野派9代目の絵師である。
sen.e: Osanobu Kano (born August 18, 1796; died June 12, 1846) was the ninth head of the Kobikicho-Kano-ha, and Edo Period school of painting.
sen.cmt: 9代目の絵師 is a somewhat unclear expression. Was he the 9th leader? The ninth to become famous, or pass some qualification, or what?
sen.e: Osanobu Kano (born August 18, 1796; died June 12, 1846) was the ninth painter of the Kobikicho Kano School in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: originalには確かにあいまいな点がありますが、用語集の定訳等にのっとり、一部修正しました。
sen.e: Osanobu Kano (born August 18, 1796; died June 12, 1846) was the ninth painter of the Kobikicho Kano School in the Edo period.

sen.j: 通称、庄三郎。
sen.e: He usually went by the name Shozaburo.
sen.cmt: It is not clear as to whether this is all the name or includes a family name and a name.
sen.e: His common name was Shozaburo.
sen.cmt: 用語集の定訳にのっとり修正。
sen.e: His common name was Shozaburo.

sen.j: 父は狩野栄信、子に狩野雅信。
sen.e: His father was Naganobu KANO, and Tadanobu KANO was his son.
His father was Naganobu KANO, and Tadanobu KANO was his son.
His father was Naganobu KANO, and Tadanobu KANO was his son.

sen.j: 号は晴川院、会心斎、玉川。
sen.e: His names include Osanobu SEISENIN, Kaishinsai, and Tamagawa.
sen.cmt: The meaning of 号 is unlcear.
sen.e: His Go (pen name) was Osanobu Seisenin, Kaishinsai, and Gyokusen.
sen.cmt: SEISENIN → Seisenin。ネット上に記載はありませんが、 「玉川」はTamagawa ではなくGyokusen の可能性があります。6つ下のセルで、「玉樹院」と「玉川」が「音通」するとの記載があります。
sen.e: His Go (pen name) was Osanobu Seisenin, Kaishinsai, and Gyokusen.

sen.j: 略歴
sen.e: Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History

sen.j: 伊川院栄信の長男として江戸で生まれる。
sen.e: He was born the eldest son of Naganobu ISENIN during the Edo period.
He was born the eldest son of Naganobu ISENIN during the Edo period.
He was born the eldest son of Naganobu ISENIN during the Edo period.

sen.j: 15歳で初めて江戸城に出仕し、しばしば父親から観能会などの公務を押しつけられたようだ。
sen.e: He was first sent to serve at Edo Castle at the age of 15, and it appears that he was apparently pushed by his father to perform various public tasks for the Kanon School.
sen.cmt: no definition for 観能会 in the database
sen.e: He was first sent to serve at Edo Castle at the age of 15, and it appears that he was apparently pushed by his father to perform various public tasks for the Kanon School.
He was first sent to serve at Edo Castle at the age of 15, and it appears that he was apparently pushed by his father to perform various public tasks for the Kanon School.

sen.j: 出仕する前日から、没する前日までの36年間にもわたる。
sen.e: He kept a diary for 36 years, starting from the day before he first went into service at Edo Castle until the day before he died.
sen.cmt: no translation for 公用日記 or 諸家分蔵 in the database. Also, this sentence should be two sentences, as I have rendered it. 一原文一訳文の例外対処 （チェック校正者による）。
sen.e: He kept a diary for 36 years, starting from the day before he first went into service at Edo Castle until the day before he died.
He kept a diary for 36 years, starting from the day before he first went into service at Edo Castle until the day before he died.

sen.j: 『公用日記』（52冊は東京国立博物館蔵、4冊は諸家分蔵）は奥絵師の日常や仕事の詳細を伝えるものとして近年注目されている
sen.e: The diary is entitles "Official Service Diary" (it consists of 52 volumes that are maintained at the Tokyo National Museum, and 4 volumes that are maintained at the ???), and have become the focus of a lot of attention in recent years for the detailed information they present on the daily life and work of a prestigious official painter.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処 （チェック校正者による）。
sen.e: The diary is entitles "Official Service Diary" (it consists of 52 volumes that are maintained at the Tokyo National Museum, and 4 volumes that are separately maintained at the different families), and have become the focus of a lot of attention in recent years for the detailed information they present on the daily life and work of a prestigious official painter.
sen.cmt: 「諸家分蔵」・・・「???」→「separately maintained at the different families」
sen.e: The diary is entitles "Official Service Diary" (it consists of 52 volumes that are maintained at the Tokyo National Museum, and 4 volumes that are separately maintained at the different families), and have become the focus of a lot of attention in recent years for the detailed information they present on the daily life and work of a prestigious official painter.

sen.j: もともと、養信の読みは「たけのぶ」であったが、文化 (元号)10年（1813年）、将軍徳川家慶に長男竹千代が生まれると、「たけ」の音が同じで失礼だとして「おさのぶ」によみ改めた。
sen.e: The reading of the characters of his name was originally "Takenobu"; however, with the birth of the first son of the Shongun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA in 1813, whose name was Takechiyo, having a sylable with the same pronunciation of "Take"was deemed to be inappropriate, and was therefore changed to "Osanobu".

The reading of the characters of his name was originally "Takenobu"; however, with the birth of the first son of the Shongun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA in 1813, whose name was Takechiyo, having a sylable with the same pronunciation of "Take"was deemed to be inappropriate, and was therefore changed to "Osanobu".

The reading of the characters of his name was originally "Takenobu"; however, with the birth of the first son of the Shongun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA in 1813, whose name was Takechiyo, having a sylable with the same pronunciation of "Take"was deemed to be inappropriate, and was therefore changed to "Osanobu".

sen.j: さらに、この竹千代が翌年亡くなり玉樹院と呼ばれたため、それまでの号・玉川を音通を避け晴川とした。
sen.e: Because Takenobu died the following year, after which he was referred to as Gykujuin, Osanobu changed his name to SEISENIN in order to avoid misidentification due to the homonym Tamagawa he had used until that point.
sen.cmt: There is too much missing inforamtion to accurately translate this passage, particularly in relation to the 号 Tamagawa, and the like.
sen.e: Because Takenobu died the following year, after which he was referred to as Gyokujuin, Osanobu changed his pen name Gyokusen he had used until that point to Seisenin, in order to avoid using the same Chinese charcter pronounced alike.
sen.cmt: Gykujuin → Gyokujuin. および、「音通」が正しく英訳されていなかったので、その部分を修正。
sen.e: Because Takenobu died the following year, after which he was referred to as Gyokujuin, Osanobu changed his pen name Gyokusen he had used until that point to Seisenin, in order to avoid using the same Chinese charcter pronounced alike.

sen.j: 文政2年（1819年）に法眼になり、文政11年（1828年）父の死により家督を相続。
sen.e: In 1819, he attained the second highest rank for a Buddhist priest, Hogen, and assumed the role of head of the family after his father passed away in 1828.
sen.cmt: Again, these three events are not directly related, so it has to be two sentence. THIS EDITING MEANS EXTRA WORK AND NO PAY FOR THE TRANSLATOR. Is that the intention??? 一原文一訳文の例外対処 （チェック校正者による）
sen.e: In 1819, he attained the second highest rank for a Buddhist priest, Hogen, and assumed the role of head of the family after his father passed away in 1828.
In 1819, he attained the second highest rank for a Buddhist priest, Hogen, and assumed the role of head of the family after his father passed away in 1828.

sen.j: 天保5年（1834年）法印に叙せられた。
sen.e: In 1834 he attained the highest rank for a Buddhist priest, Hoin.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処 （チェック校正者による）。
sen.e: In 1834 he attained the highest rank for a Buddhist priest, Hoin.
In 1834 he attained the highest rank for a Buddhist priest, Hoin.

sen.j: 天保9年から10年（1838年から1839年）には江戸城西の丸御殿、天保15年から弘化3年（1844年から1846年）には本丸御殿の障壁画再建の総指揮を執った。
sen.e: He spent a year from 1838 to 1839 at Honmaru Palace of Edo-jo Castle, and oversaw the rennovation of the wall paintings of Hommaru Palace during the years from 1844 to 1846.
He oversaw the rennovation of the wall paintings of Nishinomaru Palace of Edo Castle from 1838 to 1839, and Honmaru Palace of it from 1844 to 1846.
sen.cmt: 二つの御所で障壁画再建の総指揮を執ったことが反映されていなかったので修正。
sen.e: He oversaw the rennovation of the wall paintings of Nishinomaru Palace of Edo Castle from 1838 to 1839, and Honmaru Palace of it from 1844 to 1846.

sen.j: 養信がその後亡くなったのは、生来病弱な上に、相次ぐ激務による疲れであろう。
sen.e: It is thought that Osanobu later died due of natural causes simply due to the fatigue endured in his endless exertions moving steadily from one project to another.
It is thought that Osanobu later died due to the fatigue endured in his endless exertions moving steadily from one project to another, in addition to his weak constitution.
sen.cmt: 「生来病弱な上に」が反映されていないので修正。
sen.e: It is thought that Osanobu later died due to the fatigue endured in his endless exertions moving steadily from one project to another, in addition to his weak constitution.

sen.j: 模写にかける情熱
sen.e: He was an avid copier of scrolls.
His passion for copying.
sen.cmt: original の意味が反映されていないので修正。
sen.e: His passion for copying.

sen.j: 養信は、模写に尋常ならざる情熱を注いだ。
sen.e: Osanobu had a zeal for zeal for copying scrolls, and continually devoting a lot of energy to that.
Osanobu had a zeal for copying scrolls, and continually devoting a lot of energy to that.
sen.cmt: "zeal for zeal for"・・・ミスタイプと思われるので修正。
sen.e: Osanobu had a zeal for copying scrolls, and continually devoting a lot of energy to that.

sen.j: 東京国立博物館にあるものだけでも、絵巻150巻、名画500点以上にも及ぶ。
sen.e: The Tokyo national Museum alone holds copies of 150 picture scrolls and 500 paintings by Osanobu in its collection.
The Tokyo national Museum alone holds copies of 150 picture scrolls and 500 paintings by Osanobu in its collection.
The Tokyo national Museum alone holds copies of 150 picture scrolls and 500 paintings by Osanobu in its collection.

sen.j: 原本の剥落や虫損まで忠実に写し取り、既にに模本から模写済みの作品でも、原本やより良い模本にめぐり合えば再度写し直している。
sen.e: He faithfully reproduced details such as damage to the original scrolls due to peeling, insects and the like, and would redo a copy if he later found a better specimen or the like.
He faithfully reproduced details such as damage to the original scrolls due to peeling, insects and the like, and would redo a copy if he later found a better specimen or the like.
He faithfully reproduced details such as damage to the original scrolls due to peeling, insects and the like, and would redo a copy if he later found a better specimen or the like.

sen.j: 関心も多岐にわたり、高野山学侶宝蔵の調度、舞楽面、装束を写した6巻や、掛け軸の表装の紙や裂まで描いてあるものもあり、養信の旺盛な学習意欲が伺われる。
sen.e: Osanobu's interests were diverse, and his active pursuit of learning can be seen in his six scrolls on the furnishings at the Treasure House of the Koyasan Gakuryo, Bugaku (court dance and music) masks, and costumes, as well as the fact that he even drew the paper monutings and tears of hanging scrolls when he copied them.
sen.cmt: somewhat unclear. No, actually this is a VERY unclear and incoherent Japanese sentence.
sen.e: Osanobu's interests were diverse, and his active pursuit of learning can be seen in his six scrolls on the furnishings Gakuryo, Bugaku (court dance and music) masks, and costumes at the Treasure House of the Koyasan, as well as the fact that he even drew the paper mountings and tears of hanging scrolls when he copied them.
sen.cmt: 「高野山学侶宝蔵の調度、舞楽面、装束」の部分、「高野山学侶宝蔵」は以下３つの物にかかると思われるので修正。monutings → mountings のスペルミスを修正。
sen.e: Osanobu's interests were diverse, and his active pursuit of learning can be seen in his six scrolls on the furnishings Gakuryo, Bugaku (court dance and music) masks, and costumes at the Treasure House of the Koyasan, as well as the fact that he even drew the paper mountings and tears of hanging scrolls when he copied them.

sen.j: 150巻という数字に表れているように、特に古絵巻の模写に心血を注いぎ多くの逸話が残る。
sen.e: As is demonstrated by the high number of 150 scrolls, and can be seen in particular in the many extant masterful copies he made of ancient scrolls, Osanobu poured his heart and soul into this work.
As is demonstrated by the high number of 150 scrolls, and can be seen in particular in the many extant masterful copies he made of ancient scrolls, Osanobu left a lot of legends behind.
sen.cmt: 「多くの逸話が残る」が反映されていなかったので修正。
sen.e: As is demonstrated by the high number of 150 scrolls, and can be seen in particular in the many extant masterful copies he made of ancient scrolls, Osanobu left a lot of legends behind.

sen.j: 将軍家の倉からはもちろん、松平定信の白河文庫、住吉家をはじめ諸家から原本や模本を借りては写し、京都の寺の出開帳があれば写しに出向いた。
sen.e: Osanobu would borrow originals or copies from the storehouse of the Shogunate families, of course, as well as from the libraries of Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, the SUMISYOSHI family and others, make copies, and if there was a Dekaicho (exhibiting a Buddhist image) at a temple in Kyoto he would set out for Kyoto to draw it.

Osanobu would borrow originals or copies from the storehouse of the Shogunate families, of course, as well as from the Shirakawa Bunko library of Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, and those of the SUMISYOSHI family and others, make copies, and if there was a Dekaicho (exhibiting a Buddhist image) at a temple in Kyoto he would set out for Kyoto to draw it.

Osanobu would borrow originals or copies from the storehouse of the Shogunate families, of course, as well as from the Shirakawa Bunko library of Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, and those of the SUMISYOSHI family and others, make copies, and if there was a Dekaicho (exhibiting a Buddhist image) at a temple in Kyoto he would set out for Kyoto to draw it.

sen.j: さらに、公務でに江戸を離れられない自分の代わりに、京都・奈良に弟子を派遣して写させ、ついにはどこの寺からでも宝物を取り寄せられるように、寺社奉行から許可まで取り付けた。
sen.e: In addition, because he was not able to leave his official duties in Edo, he would dispatch his apprentices to Kyoto and Nara to copy works, and had received permission from the jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines) enabling him to continually borrow treasured works from temples and shrines so he could make copies.

In addition, because he was not able to leave his official duties in Edo, he would dispatch his apprentices to Kyoto and Nara to copy works, and had received permission from the jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines) enabling him to continually borrow treasured works from temples and shrines so he could make copies.

In addition, because he was not able to leave his official duties in Edo, he would dispatch his apprentices to Kyoto and Nara to copy works, and had received permission from the jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines) enabling him to continually borrow treasured works from temples and shrines so he could make copies.

sen.j: その情熱は、死の12日前まで当時細川家にあった蒙古襲来絵詞を写していたほどで、生涯衰えることはなかった。
sen.e: His zeal was such that it did not fade throughout his lifetime, as can be seen from the fact that up till twelve days before he passed away he was engaged in copying the Moko Shurai Ekotoba, which was then in the possession of the Hosokawa family.

His zeal was such that it did not fade throughout his lifetime, as can be seen from the fact that up till twelve days before he passed away he was engaged in copying the Moko Shurai Ekotoba, which was then in the possession of the Hosokawa family.

His zeal was such that it did not fade throughout his lifetime, as can be seen from the fact that up till twelve days before he passed away he was engaged in copying the Moko Shurai Ekotoba, which was then in the possession of the Hosokawa family.

sen.j: 最も早い時期の模写は数え11歳の時であり、父である栄信の指導、発想があったのではと疑われる。
sen.e: He first tried his hand at copying at the age of eleven, and is thought to have been undertaken under the instruction of his father, Naganobu.
He first tried his hand at copying at the age of eleven, and is thought to have been undertaken under the instruction of his father, Naganobu.
He first tried his hand at copying at the age of eleven, and is thought to have been undertaken under the instruction of his father, Naganobu.

sen.j: そうした模写の中には、江戸城西の丸御殿や本丸御殿の襖金碧障壁画など、現存しない物や原本所在不明な物も含まれており、研究者にとっては貴重な資料である。
sen.e: Among those early works are copies made of the kinpeki-shohekiga (paintings on gold foil-pressed paper sliding doors and screens) of the Nishimaru Palace of Edo castle, the Honmaru Palace of Edo-jo Castle and the like, including works that are no longer extant, or of which the wherabouts are unknown, making them extremely valuable sources to researchers.
sen.cmt: somewhat unclear. No term search for 江戸城西の丸御殿
sen.e: Among those early works are copies made of the Fusuma kinpeki-shohekiga (paintings on gold foil-pressed paper sliding doors and screens) of the Nishinomaru Palace and the Honmaru Palace of Edo-jo Castle and the like, including works that are no longer extant, or of which the whereabouts are unknown, making them extremely valuable sources to researchers.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ・・・「襖」。 wherabout → whereabout
sen.e: Among those early works are copies made of the Fusuma kinpeki-shohekiga (paintings on gold foil-pressed paper sliding doors and screens) of the Nishinomaru Palace and the Honmaru Palace of Edo-jo Castle and the like, including works that are no longer extant, or of which the whereabouts are unknown, making them extremely valuable sources to researchers.

sen.j: 狩野典信以来、木挽町家に引き継がれてきた古画の学習を、養信は一段とおしすすめ、大和絵を完全に自らの画風に取り入れた。
sen.e: Since Michinobu KANO, the study of ancient paintings succeeded by the Kobikicho house has advanced one step beyond the level Osanobu Kano, completely mastering and incorporating the techniques of Yamato-e painting (a traditional Japanese style painting of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes).

Osanobu further advanced the study of ancient paintings succeeded for generations in the Kobikicho house since Michinobu KANO, and completely mastered and incorporated the techniques of Yamato-e painting (a traditional Japanese style painting of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes) into his painting style.
sen.cmt: original の意味が正しく反映されていなかったので修正。
sen.e: Osanobu further advanced the study of ancient paintings succeeded for generations in the Kobikicho house since Michinobu KANO, and completely mastered and incorporated the techniques of Yamato-e painting (a traditional Japanese style painting of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes) into his painting style.

sen.j: これは、江戸狩野派の祖狩野探幽がめざし、狩野元信以来狩野派の課題であった漢画と大和絵の対立を昇華した養信の重要な業績である。
sen.e: This was the aim of the founder of the Edo Kano school of painting, Tanyu KANO, and the project of the Kano school since the time of Motonobu KANO has been to contrast the differences between Chinese style painting and Yamato-e painting,, which was an important achievement of the sublime works of Osanobu.

This was an important achievement of the sublime works of Osanobu, who contrasted the differences between Chinese style painting and Yamato-e painting, which was the aim of the founder of the Edo Kano school of painting, Tanyu KANO, as well as the project of the Kano school since the time of Motonobu KANO.
sen.cmt: 「江戸狩野派の祖狩野探幽がめざし、狩野元信以来狩野派の課題であった」の両方が次の言葉にかかると思われるので、修正。
sen.e: This was an important achievement of the sublime works of Osanobu, who contrasted the differences between Chinese style painting and Yamato-e painting, which was the aim of the founder of the Edo Kano school of painting, Tanyu KANO, as well as the project of the Kano school since the time of Motonobu KANO.

sen.j: 平成15年（2003年）養信の墓が移転される際、遺骨が掘り出され頭部が復元された。
sen.e: When the grave of Osanobu was moved in 2003, after exhuming his bones, his skull and face were reconstructed.
sen.cmt: these expressions all lack sufficient detail. Did they reconstruct his face? Or just the skull?
sen.e: When the grave of Osanobu was moved in 2003, his bones were exhumed and his skull and face were reconstructed.
sen.cmt: original の意味が理解されていなかったので修正。
sen.e: When the grave of Osanobu was moved in 2003, his bones were exhumed and his skull and face were reconstructed.

sen.j: その面長で端整な顔立ちは、几帳面で消化器系が弱かったという養信の人物像を彷彿とさせる。
sen.e: It is thought, based on his oval shaped, graceful face, that Osanobu was a fastidious individual with a somewhat weak digestive tract.
sen.cmt: It seems a bit unscientific, but maybe I just don't understand the Japanese.
sen.e: It is thought, based on his oval shaped, graceful face, that Osanobu was a fastidious individual with a somewhat weak digestive tract.
It is thought, based on his oval shaped, graceful face, that Osanobu was a fastidious individual with a somewhat weak digestive tract.

sen.j: この復元模型は、池上本門寺で保管されている。
sen.e: The reconstructed model is maintained by the Ikegami Honmon-ji Temple.
The reconstructed model is maintained by the Ikegami Honmon-ji Temple.
The reconstructed model is maintained by the Ikegami Honmon-ji Temple.

sen.j: 源氏物語図屏風（若菜・紅葉賀）（香川・法然寺）八曲一双 重要文化財
